docs.lead_paragraph: Defying a veto threat from President Bush, the Senate tonight passed a bill that would establish a wide range of patients' rights for more than 200 million Americans with health insurance. The bill would, for the first time, set detailed federal standards for private health insurance and would allow patients to file suit, in federal or state court, to enforce their rights.

headline.main: BILL ESTABLISHING PATIENTS' RIGHTS PASSES IN SENATE

docs.snippet: Defying a veto threat from President Bush, the Senate tonight passed a bill that would establish a wide range of patients' rights for more than 200 million Americans with health insurance.    The bill would, for the first time, set detailed federal...

docs.lead_paragraph: Vice President Dick Cheney said today that doctors would almost certainly implant a sophisticated heart pacemaker and defibrillator during an operation on Saturday, his third significant medical procedure to combat heart disease since he was elected vice president. Mr. Cheney, appearing in the White House press room on short notice this morning, said he had decided to have the small electronic device inserted to counter periodic episodes of rapid heart rhythms, a problem that often develops among patients with a history of heart attacks. A final decision will be made after tests on Saturday morning.

headline.main: CHENEY'S DOCTORS EXPECT TO IMPLANT DEVICE FOR HEART

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Dick Cheney says doctors will almost certainly implant sophisticated heart pacemaker and defibrillator to counter periodic episodes of rapid heart rhythms, problem that often develops among patients with history of heart attacks; says they have assured him that device, called implantable cardioverter defibrillator, will not impair his ability to do his job; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-7 U.N. War Crimes Tribunal Expands Milosevic Charges The war crimes tribunal in The Hague issued an expanded indictment against Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, charging him with additional atrocities and naming more victims of war crimes during the 1999 conflict in Kosovo. Carla Del Ponte, the chief prosecutor, pressed for the arrest of 38 other people indicted for war crimes who are still at large. A7

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I agree with Marcia Angell (Op-Ed, June 23) that a patients' rights bill will make a bad situation worse, but I do not agree with her single-payer solution.
docs.abstract: Richard L Huber letter on Marcia Angell's June 23 Op-Ed arguing that patients' rights bill will make bad situation worse; contends that single-payer is not the solution, citing disastrous results of Canadian and British systems
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    I agree with Marcia Angell (Op-Ed, June 23) that a patients' rights bill will make a bad situation worse, but I do not agree with her single-payer solution.

docs.lead_paragraph: Lobbying Is in Full Swing From Microsoft and Rivals As federal and state prosecutors ponder what to do next with Microsoft, they have already come under enormous lobbying pressure from the company to quickly settle and from its rivals, most notably AOL Time Warner, to continue litigating. The lobbying campaign was in full swing even before the decision by a federal court of appeals on Thursday that vacated the order to break up Microsoft but also found that the company had engaged in a raft of anticompetitive practices. [Page A1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from the news conference yesterday in Washington at which Vice President Cheney announced that he might have a cardiac pacemaker implanted, as recorded by Federal News Service Inc.: STATEMENT I'm going to undergo a test tomorrow at George Washington University Hospital. It's called an electrophysiology study. And it specifically is performed for the purpose of determining the prospective risk for me going forward in terms of abnormal heart rhythms. For somebody with my background and record with respect to coronary artery disease and previous heart attacks, there is that possibility of abnormal heartbeats.

docs.lead_paragraph: The shape of Senate legislation to define patients' rights became clear today as Democrats pressed for swift passage of the bill and Republican senators accepted the prospect of defeat on major issues of concern to President Bush. Having agreed on the guts of the bill -- a long list of protections for patients -- the Senate spent most of the day slogging through a series of amendments.

headline.main: Bush Faces Defeat on Patients' Rights Bill

A1 Powell Sets Mideast Timetable Secretary of State Colin L. Powell announced a seven-week timetable for restoring political talks between Israel and the Palestinians. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Minnesota lawmakers pushed through a flurry of compromises and votes today that legislative leaders hoped could help stave off Gov. Jesse Ventura's threat of a partial state government shutdown. But the battle over the state's major spending bills, among the Democratic-controlled Senate, the Republican-controlled House and an independent governor, was not yet resolved. Four spending measures and one major tax bill have been passed and sent to Governor Ventura. Four more spending bills were outstanding this evening, although an agreement was reached on one of them, a health and human services bill that contained disputed issues involving abortion and health insurance.

headline.main: Minnesota Lawmakers Rush To Avoid a State Shutdown

docs.abstract: Minnesota lawmakers push through flurry of compromises and votes that legislative leaders hope could help stave off Gov Jesse Ventura's threat of partial state government shutdown; but battle over state's major spending bills remains unresolved; photo (M)
